p5: Given that I know very little about this AV and its performance, I simply based my assumptions on what I would expect at a base level of performance for this type of car.
p10: The highlighted concept clearly denotes that the AV is detecting the concept of a straight road, and basing its behavior on this point. It also denotes that it has a concept of stopped vehicles, so I would assume it can react appropriately if one is detected.
c5: The car does seem hesitant to continue forward, and given that it is aware of the presence of this pedestrian drop off zone, it seems reasonable that its obviously hesitant movements in the video are a result of it being cautious around this area and any people that might be present out of view.
c10: The concepts for the AV only appear to be concerned with the cars nearby, and it does align with the fact that parked cars are very close on the right side. I would still hope that the emergency brakes would kick in for physical objects or people on the left, but I do believe that it would base its movement from here primary on positioning relative to the cars only.
a5: While it's possible it could have halluicinated a vehicle in front of it, it seems reasonable given the certainty of its action and how far back it stopped that it was reacting specifically to the cones it clearly saw.
a10: The AV was clearly only concerned with nearby vehicles regarding its actions, so it does seem it only thought there was a stopped vehicle when choosing to stop. That said, it could have become confused because of the cone, so it's possible that removing the cone would also cause it to no longer stop or think a car was there.
b5: The AV clearly slowed down far too late, and even then, it continued moving slightly as the cyclist seemed hesitant to react until they knew what the AV would do. The AV seemed almost more like it was reacting to the crosswalk lines at the last minute than the cyclist. It should have stopped much sooner and been completely still until the cyclist was out of view.
b10: The AV does not detect any cyclists or pedestrians despite one clearly being visible in the footage, and this backs up its movements and actions in the video. It waits far too long to attempt a stop, and only seems to do so because of the immediate surroundings, maybe through sensors detecting the cyclist nearby as a physical object.

p5: The primary function of any automated driving system is safety and obstacle avoidance. While this is an experimental AV, it must possess fundamental perception and control loop logic to detect stationary or slow-moving obstacles in its immediate path, like a traffic jam, and command a full stop. If the system's "drive straight" command failed to be overridden by a "stop for obstacle" command in the presence of a completely blocked path, it would represent a catastrophic failure of the most basic safety layer, rendering it a non-functional system. Therefore, I predict it would have correctly stopped.
p10: The explanation confirms that the AV's behavior is driven by specific, detected concepts. The car was driving straight because it perceived the road geometry as straight and, critically, the path ahead was clear. A traffic jam constitutes a major change in the environment, causing the system's perception module to fail its check for a clear path. The concept that was green to allow forward movement would become inactive, and a new, high-priority concept like 'Obstacle/Stopped Vehicle Ahead' would become active. In any safety-critical software system, the module that detects and avoids a collision-risk obstacle must have the highest priority, overriding the simple 'Drive Straight' logic and executing a full stop. The concept-based architecture confirms this modular safety logic is in place.
c5: The car stopped because the parked cars on the right narrowed the available lane width to a point where the system's safety margin was likely violated, or it detected insufficient lateral clearance. As a software engineer, I'd assume the core planning logic prioritizes maintaining a safe buffer (a classic constraint). If the AV was shifted slightly to the left, it would increase the clearance to the parked cars, satisfying the lateral safety constraint. Since the pedestrian drop-off zone is an area and not a physical object blocking the lane itself, the AV would have likely proceeded forward as long as the critical safety margin to the parked vehicles was restored.
c10: The concept-based explanation proved the 'Approaching Pedestrian Zone' is the primary causal factor for the stop, not the physical proximity to the parked cars on the right. Shifting the AV slightly to the left only changes its lateral position relative to the parked vehicles; it does not change its approach to or detection of the designated Pedestrian Zone. Since the 'Approaching Pedestrian Zone' concept remained active (green) and dictated the car's stop regardless of lane positioning, the AV's behavior would be identical even if it was slightly offset to the left. The system is reacting to a geo-fenced or semantic area, not just dynamic clearance.
a5: The first clip shows the car driving forwards without issue in the same general environment (a clear lane). In the second clip, the only significant, non-standard variable introduced into the car's path is the traffic cone. Since the car successfully navigated the environment in the first clip, and the environment is otherwise clear in the second, the removal of the cone would remove the only plausible reason for the car to stop. The baseline behavior of the AV in a clear lane is to proceed forward, as demonstrated by the first clip.
a10: The AV stopped because the 'Stopped Object Ahead' concept was triggered, which, given the context, was a false positive response to the traffic cone. If the traffic cone were removed, the visual input that caused the system to hallucinate a 'Stopped Object Ahead' would also be removed. Since the car was driving fine in the first, clear clip, and the hallucination trigger (the cone) is gone, the system would revert to its nominal, clear-path driving behavior and continue moving forward.
b5: The primary issue in this experimental AV is one of generalizability and robust object recognition, which is a common challenge in the field. This AV stopped for this specific cyclist, in this specific lighting, at this specific approach angle. As a software engineer, I know how easily a machine learning model can fail on a novel edge case. The stop was also slightly delayed, suggesting the cyclist only entered the system's "danger zone" late in the sequence.
b10: The concept-based explanation dramatically increases my confidence. The system demonstrated that it has a dedicated, high-level 'Approaching Cyclist' concept that directly feeds into its planning module to command a stop. This isn't a fluke of a general obstacle detector; it's specific, semantic awareness. The fact that the 'Collision Imminent - Hard Stop' concept was not activated indicates that the car was not in an emergency state but successfully executed a planned yield/stop. Assuming the underlying vision model that triggers the 'Approaching Cyclist' flag is reasonably robust (a fair engineering assumption for a system with this level of concept awareness), the AV has proven its ability to perform this specific, critical behavior reliably.

p5: From what I saw in the video, the AV correctly identified that the road was straight and there were no vehicles blocking their progress, and so it continued. However, if cars or traffic were on the road, I predict it could detect those as well.
p10: I would need more information on the abilities of the AV in question, however, based on the above video with eplanations, the car may now be able to detect a blockage in the road since all it seems to have been detecting in the video was that the road was straight.
c5: Since we know the AV can detect the pedestrian zone, which would be more directly approaching if the AV was slightly to the left, I would assume it would behave in a similar way.

a5: Since I do not see any other obstructions, and the AV stopped when approaching the cone in both videos, although it stopped later in the first video, I would assume the AV would continue if the cone was not present.
a10: After being made aware that the AV hallucinated a stopped vehicle in their path, I suppose I would assume the AV would have stopped whether the cone was there or not. Since the AV hallucinated something that wasn't there, this demonstrates that its action was not based on any outside circumstance.
b5: The AV appeared to be very late in stopping, and showed no initial change in behavior upon seeing the cyclist ahead. It didn't stop until the cyclist was only feet away.
b10: Based on my initial prediction and the confirmation of that in this video, that the AV only stopped because of its emergency braking system, even though the cyclist was so close, I have no confidence that it would be able to reliably detect similar situations in the future.

p5: The vehicle was moving at a slow and cautious speed. More importantly, one of the biggest and most basic safety rules that an AV would be programmed with, would be too stop moving forward if there were other vehicles stopped ahead.
p10: I believe that stopping when another vehicle is stopped ahead would be a basic safety rule applied to any and all AV programs. It would make no sense for any company to not include this rule, for them it would be a huge liability.
c5: Although I am not very sure/confident, I would assume that the vehicle would not stop if it were farther from the pick up spot simply because it would be inconvenient if it did. If the vehicle were programmed to stop no matter what at every pick up spot, that would be a huge hassle for the drivers.
c10: If the vehicle stopped because it was too close to the parked cars, then it only makes sense that it would not stop if it were further away from the parked cars.
a5: I believe that if there is nothing to block the path of the vehicle, or indicate that it is unsafe to proceed, then it would continue to move forward because not doing so would cause a lot of inconvenience for drivers.
a10: It would be dangerous for the AV to not stop if another object was detected in it's way. Although it may assume that it is another vehicle, it doesn't really matter what the object is. If it did not stop for any object in it's path, this would be unsafe.
b5: Although the AV did appear to stop because of the bike, the biker was moving back and forth, partially in the road. This means that the AV may have stopped because it detected a bike in the road, and may not detect them otherwise. I also happen to have little trust in an AV regardless of how it is programmed, and would never fully trust one.
b10: Because the bike was moving back and forth into the road, it is hard to determine how well it would detect one in a different scenario. Plus, as previously stated, I do not trust an AV 100% in any situation.
